citation.article-title: Description of a novel indole-oxidizing bacterium Pseudomonas indoloxydans sp. nov., isolated from a pesticide-contaminated site

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas indoloxydans sp. nov.
P. indoloxydans (in.dol.o.xy’dans N.L. n. indolum, indole; N.L. part. adj. oxydans, oxidizing; N.L. part. adj. indoloxydans, indole-oxydizing).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore forming aerobic, motile, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, short rods (0.8–1.0×2.0–2.5 μm).
The colonies are deep brown pigmented, circular, opaque and convex, with a smooth margin on TSA.
Strain IPL-1T does not produce fluorescent pigment.
Growth occurs at 10–42 °C (optimal temperature is 30 °C), at a pH of 6.5–9.0 (optimal pH is 7.0) and at 2.5–5.0% (w/v) NaCl.
The strain grows on Simmon's citrate and MacConkey agar, and reduces nitrate to nitrite.
Tributyrin, Tween 80 and urea hydrolysis is positive, but hydrolysis of aesculin, casein, gelatin, hippurate, ONPG and starch is negative.
The strain is negative for methyl red, Voges-Proskauer, oxidation–fermentation tests and lecithinase activity.
It is capable of producing indigo by indole oxidation.
Oxidation of substrates for growth and acid production from carbohydrates under aerobic conditions are shown in Table 1.
Arginine dihydrolase, phenylalanine deaminase, lysine and ornithine decarboxylase activities are negative.
H2S and indole are not produced.
The major isoprenoid quinone is Ub-9 (Q-9).
The predominant fatty acids are C18:1ω7c (38.1%), summed feature 3 (C16:1ω7c/iso C15:0 2OH, 22.7%), C16:0 (19.2%) and C12:0 (8.8%).
The DNA G+C content is 67.2 mol%.
The type strain IPL-1T (=MTCC 8062T=JCM 14246T) was isolated from a lindane manufacturing industrial site, Lucknow, India.
